abstract: Background: Estimation of the magnitude of the herd effect on invasive pneumococcal disease (IPD) is important when evaluating health benefits and cost-effectiveness of paediatric pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV) programmes and may influence policy makers’ decisions on PCV use. Several epidemiological, programmatic, and immunological factors can affect the magnitude of the PCV herd effect. We investigated to what extent the choice of analytical methodology may also influence herd effect estimates. Methods: To estimate the magnitude of the herd effect from paediatric PCV programmes, we examined overall IPD incidence rates in ≥65-year-olds from Finland, Australia, England/Wales, and the United States under different analytical scenarios. We used two different statistical methods: before/after comparison of average IPD incidence rates and interrupted time series (ITS) analysis accounting for underlying time trends. We also investigated how varying the length of the pre- and post-PCV analysis periods influenced the outcomes. Results: The estimated impact of paediatric PCV programmes on IPD incidence rates in adults ≥65 years varied substantially across the different scenarios within each country. The choice of statistical method and analysis periods contributed to this variation, and their influence varied by setting. For the datasets from England/Wales and the United States, the different scenarios produced relatively minor variation in estimated impact. For the Australian and Finnish datasets, differences were more prominent. In particular, for Finland, opposite conclusions could be drawn depending on the methodology: while no estimated herd effect was seen with the before/after method, a herd effect was evident with the ITS method. Conclusions: The choice of statistical method and analysis periods can substantially influence the magnitude of estimated herd effects from paediatric PCV programmes. It is important to consider the reliability and presence of pre-PCV patterns in the IPD surveillance data used for analysis, the methodology and associated assumptions used to estimate herd effects.

author_highlights.sentence: Data on PCV herd effects may influence policy makers’ decisions on PCV use.
We investigated to what extent analytical methodology influences PCV herd effect estimates.
We used different statistical methods and analysis periods on IPD surveillance data from 4 countries.
We show that the choice of statistical method and analysis periods affects PCV herd effect estimates.

body_text.title: Discussion

body_text.sentence: The influence of the choice of analytical methodology may have differed had we investigated additional scenarios using other statistical methods or analysis periods, or had we included datasets from less well-established surveillance networks, with fewer years of surveillance available, or with lower case counts, which would have likely led to inaccurate IR estimates and erroneous conclusions about PCV programs.
body_text.title: Discussion

body_text.sentence: Another approach, taken in a pooled analysis of changes in IPD rates after PCV7 introduction across multiple surveillance sites, assumed that pre-PCV7 IPD trends continued until three years post-PCV7 introduction [5].
body_text.title: Discussion

body_text.sentence: The estimated PCV7 impact on overall IPD in ≥65-year-olds ranged from a 24.2% to 30.9% decrease in IPD IRs (all 95% CIs excluding zero) when using the before/after method and from a 20.3% to 53.3% decrease (95% CIs excluding zero for 4/7 estimates) when using the ITS method.
body_text.title: Australia

body_text.sentence: As this could impact the magnitude of herd effects, we conducted additional analyses that—for each scenario—either included or excluded the year after vaccine introduction (considered as a transition year).
body_text.title: Analysis periods

body_text.sentence: Baseline data may also be difficult to obtain for many low-to-middle income countries with weak IPD surveillance systems.
body_text.title: Discussion

body_text.sentence: While most studies report substantial herd effects on VT IPD [4–11], considerable heterogeneity in the magnitude of reported herd effects on overall IPD has been observed between studies.
body_text.title: Discussion

body_text.sentence: Finally, when interpreting the magnitude of PCV herd effects it is important to assess the reliability of the IPD surveillance data used for analysis, the presence of pre-vaccine patterns or trends, the methodology used to obtain the estimate, and any assumptions made in the selection of or inherent to a specific statistical approach.
body_text.title: Conclusions

body_text.sentence: By contrast, using the ITS method, 14/17 different scenarios produced decreases, with point estimates ranging between 3.4% and 46.1%.
body_text.title: Finland

body_text.sentence: When using the before/after method, the PCV7 impact estimates varied between a 7.4% and 11.3% decrease in IPD IRs (all 95% CIs excluding zero).
body_text.title: England and Wales

body_text.sentence: In the countries included in our analyses, pneumococcal vaccines were used in adults ≥65 years of age, with some changes in recommendations occurring during the time periods included in our analyses.
body_text.title: Discussion

body_text.sentence: For the US dataset, we applied 10 different scenarios to estimate PCV7 herd effects and 16 to estimate PCV13 herd effects (Fig. 5A).
body_text.title: United States

body_text.sentence: The second year of FinIP enrolment (2010) corresponded to the year of PHiD-CV introduction and was thus excluded from all scenarios.
body_text.title: Analysis periods

body_text.sentence: For PCV13, both methods yielded impact estimates that were generally in the same range: from a 12.5% to a 22.5% decrease for before/after and from a 20.8% to a 29.5% decrease for ITS.
body_text.title: England and Wales

body_text.sentence: We applied 8 and 10 different scenarios on the dataset from England and Wales to estimate PCV7 and PCV13 herd effects, respectively (Fig. 4A).
body_text.title: England and Wales

body_text.sentence: However, as mass vaccination of infants and children with PCVs not only results in population-level decreases in VT disease but can also be accompanied by increases in NVT disease [5,12], the overall herd effect from a paediatric PCV programme is best reflected by its impact on the total burden of pneumococcal disease in a non-PCV-vaccinated population, regardless of causative serotype, with invasive pneumococcal disease (IPD) being the most frequently measured outcome.
body_text.title: Introduction

body_text.sentence: However, even small quantitative differences in the magnitude of the estimated herd effects obtained with the two methods could still have significant health economic implications.
body_text.title: Discussion

body_text.sentence: These results highlight the importance of considering the analytical methodology when estimating and interpreting herd effects and when comparing herd effect estimates from different studies.
body_text.title: Discussion

body_text.sentence: The influence of the choice of analytical methodology on the magnitude of estimated herd effects has been less well studied.
body_text.title: Introduction

body_text.sentence: WPH is also patent co-holder for PCV13 but receives no royalties as per industry practice.
body_text.title: Disclosures

metadata.title: The choice of analytical methodology can alter conclusions regarding herd effects of paediatric pneumococcal vaccination programmes
